thread.title: AFL 2015: Geelong thumps Brisbane Lions at Simonds Stadium in Round 18 | The
thread.title_full: AFL 2015: Geelong thumps Brisbane Lions at Simonds Stadium in Round 18 | The Advertiser

author: Scott Gullan
title: AFL 2015: Geelong thumps Brisbane Lions at Simonds Stadium in Round 18 | The
text:
A CAREER-BEST from one and movement up the all-time list by another forward was the story of a regulation day at the office for Geelong.
While some may question where the Cats are at, what is known is that there is still a significant gulf between them and Brisbane.
The Lions had their moments in the first half but a three-goal blitz in as many minutes early in the third quarter got the home team rolling and from there it was just a matter of how far.
In the end Brisbane capitulated as the Cats piled on 10 goals in the second half to win by 56-points, importantly lifting its percentage significantly.
Unheralded big man Josh Walker enjoyed the feast kicking a career-high five goals, including four in the first half.
But the biggest cheer of the day was for crowd favourite Steve Johnson who moved to third on the club’s all-time goal kicking list.
Joel Selwood starred with two goals and 27 disposals, but it certainly wasn’t all smooth-sailing for the Cats skipper. Picture: Colleen Petch Source: News Corp Australia
The moment he went past his good mate Billy Brownless came at the six-minute mark of the third quarter when he converted a set shot from 40m.
That was his 442nd goal of his career but he will have to settle for third given the great Gary Ablett holds the club record on 1021 with Doug Wade a distant second with 834.
The other interest for the locals was voicing their displeasure every time Allen Christensen went near the ball.
His former teammates were certainly keen to let him know they weren’t going to make his return a nice visit, crashing into him at every opportunity.
Christensen managed to just 12 touches and had minimal impact on the game but he wasn’t on his lonesome there.
Other key playmakers such as Pearce Hanley (17 disposals) and Daniel Rich (19) were well down also while Dayne Beams (17) appeared to hurt his shoulder again in the third term.
The Lions had only kicked nine goals in its previous two matches coming into Saturday’s game and once again they didn’t have anything resembling a forward line.
Allen Christensen only had 12 disposals in his first game back at his former home ground. Picture: Colleen Petch Source: News Corp Australia
That’s not ideal when you come up against one of the most experienced defences in the business and it was left to one of the Lions own veterans, Jed Adcock, to do the job.
He kicked four of his team’s eight goals as youngsters Jonathan Freeman and Daniel McStay struggled to have any impact against the likes of Harry Taylor, Tom Lonergan, Andrew Mackie and Corey Enright.
The Lions best was ruckman Stefan Martin who had to carry the load in the second half after Matthew Leuenberger was once again injured, hurting his knee midway the first quarter before being subbed out at half-time.
Cats press conference 6:46 Play video
AFL: Geelong coach Chris Scott speaks to the media following his team's round 18 victory over Brisbane.
Fox Sports 01 Aug 2015 Sport/AFL/News So was there anything learnt about where Geelong are at from this walk in the park?
Not a lot really.
Walker’s efforts were encouraging as the second tall forward given Mitch Clark has disappeared from the equation while Johnson showed there is still a bit of life in the old legs particularly against inferior youngsters.
The continued improvement of Josh Caddy (29 possessions) and Cameron Guthrie (28 touches) as elite midfielders was significant while captain Joel Selwood is clearly a happier person since his mid-season break.
Josh Walker took five marks. Picture: Colleen Petch Source: News Corp Australia
Steven Motlop continued his rich vein of recent form, regularly being the link man on his way to a lazy 29 possessions which included eight inside 50s.
But Chris Scott wouldn’t be pleased with a couple of his younger players who failed to jump on opportunities to have a day out.
Billie Smedts had a horror first half, dropping easy marks and had six clangers to the main break while Nakia Cockatoo came on late in the third quarter with his only noticeable piece of play a bad turnover which ended with a Lewis Taylor goal.
Lions press conference 0:47 Play video
AFL: Brisbane coach Justin Leppitsch speaks to the media following his sides round 18 loss to Geelong.
Fox Sports 01 Aug 2015 Sport/AFL/News And Shane Kersten again didn’t get involved enough with just nine disposals and no goals.
The day started particular promisingly for the Cats when Johnson snapping a goal 12 seconds into the game.
Hopes for a free-flowing offensive affair were still bubbling along at quarter time with the home team kicking five goals to two.
Unfortunately the second quarter was more a case of ring-a-ring-a-rosy with the ball spending most of the time going backwards and sideways.
Both teams were guilty of it with Walker at least keeping the punters interested by equalling his career-high of four goals by half-time.
Cameron Guthrie starred with 28 disposals and two goals. Picture: Colleen Petch Source: News Corp Australia
GEELONG 17.11 (113)
BRISBANE LIONS 8.9 (57)
GOALS
Geelong: J Walker 5, S Johnson 3, C Guthrie 2, J Selwood 2, T Hawkins 2, D Lang, J Caddy, S Motlop
Brisbane Lions: J Adcock 4, L Taylor 2, J Freeman, R Bewick
Umpires: Shaun Ryan, Leigh Fisher, Brent Wallace.
Official Crowd: 21,913 at Simonds Stadium
Originally published as Walker’s bag inspires crushing Cats win
